headSection.headingText: Отже, тут буде коротка історія того як сайт будується або будувався. Так як молодший брат FE дев, а старший - BE дев, початкова задумка була така, що, молодший практикується у BE, а старший брат у FE, таким чином перебираючи досвід один в одного, а як складеться в результаті - напишу потім :). Мені завжди було цікаво завести сайтик на якому можна буде документувати щось корисне для себе і фіксувати враження життєвих подій, щоб потім можна було із ностальгією згадувати старі історії.
headSection.headingSubText: Сайт написаний на React, гоститься за допомогою GitHub Pages. Стилізований без CSS фреймворків. Контент наразі береться із json файликів які знаходяться у сорсах, фотографії також, тому сайтик для своїх потреб можна поміняти дуже просто. BE поки що немає. Ось для прикладу лінк на json файл який містить контент для цього параграфу: <a href="https://github.com/petroborovets/rovets/blob/5c52f4dba2a5673716a8078e667ddd05f43abad6/src/constants/posts.json#L13" target="_blank">GitHub<a/>.

value: Скільки я над ним працював: 12 днів
Кількість годин на мітингах з братом: 9h

Спарування React Browser Router із Github Pages, про проблему можна почитати тут: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46056414/getting-404-for-links-with-create-react-app-deployed-to-github-pages" target="_blank">StackOverflow<a/>. Рішення було використовувати Reacts Hash Router, рішення не найкраще, так як воно псує естетику URLs, але воно швидке і працює: <a href="https://reactrouter.com/en/main/routers/create-hash-router" target="_blank">www.reactrouter.com<a/>.

headSection.headingText: Чітко памятаю момент коли робив цю фотографію, хоч це було дуже давго. На вулиці була спека, повітря було настільки гарячим, що коли ти починав рухатись, здавалось що воно густіше ніж зазвичай, із кожним кроком, ти відчував як воно обгортає твою шкіру. Ми довго йшли і були втомлені. У момент фотографії вітер подув у спину, принісши із собою прохолодні краплинки із моря. Я відчув приплив енергії.
headSection.headingSubText: Ми йшли пішохідною стежкою Брели, вона там одна єдина, дуже довга і неймовірно мальовнича. Стежка починається у місті Baška Voda і веде аж до міста Jakiruša через усе місто Brela, цікаво було подивитись чим вона закінчується.

children.value: Коротке відео про то як Софія любить красти каміння із берегів річок. Нащо? - Я ще не зрозумів, але впевнений що в тому є глибокий сенс.
Трофеї поїздки:

Камінь 2

headSection.headingText: Cycling is more than just a means of transportation, it's an invitation to explore, a journey on two wheels that merges the physical with the spiritual. As you ride, the world around you transforms - each pedal stroke propels you into a new moment, a fresh perspective.
headSection.headingSubText: The wind in your hair becomes a whisper of freedom, a reminder that you're part of something larger, something alive.

children.value: /cycling/two-wheels/1.jpeg

The road ahead unrolls like a story waiting to be told, every turn revealing a new chapter, every mile deepening your connection with the journey. The rhythmic motion of pedaling is like a heartbeat, steady and reliable, grounding you in the present while pushing you forward into the unknown.
/cycling/two-wheels/5.jpeg

In this journey, there's a unique blend of exhilaration and calm. The thrill of speed and the rush of the ride are balanced by the meditative focus that comes with the repetitive motion, the sound of tires meeting pavement, the subtle shifts in terrain. It's a dance between effort and ease, a harmony between body and mind.
/cycling/two-wheels/2.jpeg

Cycling connects you to the world in a way few other activities can. You're not just passing through the landscape; you're immersed in it, feeling every hill, every gust of wind, every ray of sunlight. It's a sensory experience that sharpens your awareness and heightens your appreciation for the simple, often overlooked details of life.
/cycling/two-wheels/6.jpeg

At the same time, cycling is a personal journey. It's a chance to test your limits, to push beyond what you thought possible, and to discover new strengths. But it's also a space for introspection, where the steady rhythm of the ride creates a quiet mental space for reflection and clarity.
/cycling/two-wheels/4.jpeg

Whether you're riding through a bustling city or along a tranquil country road, cycling offers a unique blend of adventure and serenity. It's a reminder that the journey itself is as important as the destination, that in the simple act of moving forward on two wheels, you can find both excitement and peace, challenge and comfort, freedom and connection.

headSection.headingText: I had a mixed feelings about this game, I started playing it few month after it came out and I didn't like the gameplay and after 10 or so hours of game I quit it. But now in 2024 the game had a lot of improvements and updates and I decided to give it another try.
headSection.headingSubText: I am a big fan of RPG games, but usually I play games that are placed in the medieval times (meaning there are no technologies and just a big sword :) ), My favorite game so far is the Elden ring in which I have spend more then 600 hours playing. Also played a lot of WOW (World of warcraft) but after spending so many horus playing these games I wanted something new, and this is where the Cyberpunk 2077 kicks in.

value: Overview
Gameplay experience
My build in the game
Conclusion

children.value: Genre: Action RPG
Mode: Single-player

Setting:
"Cyberpunk 2077" is set in the dystopian future of Night City, a sprawling metropolis located in the Free State of Northern California. The game takes place in the year 2077, where mega-corporations dominate every facet of life, and technology is deeply integrated into human existence. The city is divided into six distinct districts, each with its own culture, architecture, and level of danger.
gaming/cyberpunk/night_city.jpeg

The world of Cyberpunk 2077 is heavily inspired by the cyberpunk genre, featuring a blend of high-tech and low-life elements. The city is filled with advanced technology, cybernetic enhancements, and a diverse array of characters ranging from street thugs to corporate executives.

At the first time playing this game I didn't like the experience I had. But playing it for the second time it all changed. I guess the reason is that the game was constantly improving. I still have a lot of problems with the way they implemented the driving in the game, it doesn't feel realistic at all, the physics of it I mean. Also the way you experience speed - you can drive 200 mph and it feels like you drive 100kph, But that is not the selling point of this game I guess and I can understand why they didn't spend more time improving the driving experience.

The combat experience however is much better, I guess it is partially of the build I decided to play, but more on that later. The combat experience is what made me hooked to the game. There are different ways to go with it. Meaning you can build your character in many different ways. What I see is 3 ways to play it. </br> 1) Playing as a mage (using quick hacks). Which relays on injecting hacks into technologies, or people that use cyber ware (which is all people in cyberpunk). </br> 2) Weapon(ranger) Which utilizes all types of weapons as you guessed. </br> 3) Melee weapons. Yep using sword :) (My favourite)
gaming/cyberpunk/character.jpg

I decided to play with a katana weapon with a mix of using a stenciled pistol and a sniper rifle. I found that this build is really fun to play considering the fact that you can use katana to deflect bullets. </br> Most of the combat I am trying to stay in the shadows and finish off all my enemies with the silenced pistol which makes 150% more damage when you hit the head. Once I am detected I am switching to katana, and the sniper rifle is just there as the cool attribute that is affecting stealth and pistols - also shares the perks to sniper rifles. But I rarely use it.
Attributes
gaming/cyberpunk/attributes.jpg

Here you can see what Attributes I am using. </br> Reflexes - affect the movement and the katana. </br> Cool - affects the pistols, stealth and sniper rifles. </br> Other don't really affect my build.
gaming/cyberpunk/reflexes.jpg

The reflexes is one of the most interesting attributes that you can chose. It affects the movement and allows you to almost fly from one enemy to another in an instant. Allows you to make a dash which is sort of a teleport that blinks you ~10 meters.

So far I have spent around 60 hours playing this game. And I think it has a lot of progress since it lunched. The story is interesting and grips you and the combat is perfect if you chose the right build. And as for the problems, I would say they are outweighed by all the adventures. The game of course has some bugs and problems but nothing serious that ruins the gameplay. So I really recommend you to try it out!)

headSection.headingText: React, sometimes referred to as a frontend JavaScript framework, but actually is a free, open-source FE library created by Facebook. It is maintained by Meta and a community of individual developers and companies. Library can be utilized to build single-page applications, mobile apps, or server-rendered apps with frameworks such as Next.js. Since React focuses solely on the user interface and rendering components to the DOM, applications built with React often depend on additional libraries for routing and other client-side functionalities.
headSection.headingSubText: A major benefit of React is its ability to only rerender the parts of the page that have changed, thus avoiding the unnecessary re-rendering of elements that remain unchanged. React was initially released on May 29, 2013.

value: Overview
Components, props, JSX
State, events and Forms: Interactive Components
State management
How React works behind the scenes
Effects and Data Fetching
Hooks, Refs and More State
Advanced State Management: The Context API

children.value: React allows developers to create reusable UI components, manage the state of these components efficiently, and build complex interfaces with a declarative approach.
Here are some key features of React:

value: Component-Based Architecture: React encourages the development of applications using small, reusable components. Each component encapsulates its own logic and rendering, making the code more modular and easier to maintain.

Virtual DOM: React uses a virtual DOM to optimize rendering performance. When a component's state changes, React updates the virtual DOM first and then efficiently reconciles and updates only the parts of the real DOM that have changed.
Declarative Syntax: React allows developers to describe what the UI should look like for a given state using a declarative syntax, making it easier to understand and manage the code.

JSX (JavaScript XML): React uses JSX, a syntax extension that allows you to write HTML-like code within JavaScript. JSX makes the code more readable and easier to write by combining the power of JavaScript with the simplicity of HTML.

State Management: React provides a mechanism to manage component state, allowing components to respond to user inputs and other events dynamically. State management is essential for creating interactive UIs.
One-Way Data Binding: React uses one-way data binding, meaning that data flows in a single direction—from parent to child components. This makes it easier to track changes and debug applications.

React Hooks: Introduced in React 16.8, hooks are functions that let you use state and other React features without writing class components. Hooks like useState, useEffect, and useContext simplify state management and side effects.
React Router: React Router is a library for handling routing in React applications, enabling navigation between different views or pages without reloading the entire application.

children.value: Components are the building blocks of a React application. They encapsulate parts of the user interface and manage their own state and behavior. There are two types of components: Functional Components and Class Components.

value: Functional components are Functions that return React elements. They can use hooks to manage state and side effects.
Class components are ES6 classes that extend React.Component. They have lifecycle methods and can manage state using this.state.

children.value: dev/react-post/1-read-only-props.png

Props (short for properties) are a way to pass data from a parent component to a child component. Props are read-only and help to make components reusable by allowing them to receive data and configuration from their parent. So in React we have only one way data flow.
Accessing Props: In functional components, props are accessed directly as function arguments. In class components, they are accessed via this.props.
dev/react-post/2-one-way data-flow.png

JSX (JavaScript XML) is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows you to write HTML-like code within JavaScript. It makes it easier to create React elements and components. JSX is compiled to React.createElement calls, which produce JavaScript objects that describe the UI.
dev/react-post/3-jsx-rules.png
So, lets sum-up:

value: Components: Reusable pieces of UI that can be either functional or class-based.
Props: Mechanism for passing data to components, making them dynamic and reusable.
JSX: Syntax extension that allows you to write HTML-like code in JavaScript, making the creation of React elements more intuitive.

sections.heading: State, events and Forms: Interactive Components

children.value: In React, state is a core concept used to manage data that changes over time and affects how a component renders. State is an object that represents the parts of the component that can change and is managed within the component itself.
dev/react-post/7-react-naming.png
Both state and props are used to manage data within components, but they serve different purposes and have distinct characteristics.
dev/react-post/8-state-vs-props.png
Knowing when and where to use state is crucial for building efficient and maintainable React applications. Here’s a guide on how to use state effectively:
dev/react-post/11-state-where-when.png

Lets take a look at the example below.
Please check UI mockup on the right side of the diagram, we have 3 components:
- Parent: Checkout,
- Two children: Total and Promotions.
Since Promotions component uses coupons, the logical step would be to place coupons state on the component level. But we quickly realize that Total component should be aware of coupons as well. How can we solve this issue?
dev/react-post/12-state-sharing-with-sibling-component-problem.png
Solution to this problem would be to "Lift up" the State to parent Checkout component and share this state with children using props. Here is how it work:
dev/react-post/13-lifting-up-the-state.png

sections.heading: How React works behind the scenes

value:
Reacts useState hook returns an array with 2 properties:
First - current state of the property,
Second - function that you use to update the state of the property.
Ex: const [value, setValue] = useState(someValue) where someValue is an initial state of the value.
All react functions that start with use keyword are react hooks.
You can only call hooks on the top level of component function.
What is Derived State? - Derived State: state that is computed from an existing peace of state or from props.

Component vs Instance vs Element:
- Component is a code blueprint,
- Instance is a "physical" representation of the component.
- Element: Now, as we know components return JSX which is converted to React.createElement function calls, so Element is a result of usage of Component in our code -it is simply a big immutable javascript object that React keeps in memory. React Element contains all necessary information in order to create DOM elements for the current component instance.

headSection.headingText: Century ride is a road cycling event covering 100 kilometers or more in metric system countries, or 100 miles (160.9 km) or more in imperial system countries, typically organized by cycling clubs. Many clubs host an annual century ride as a social gathering for cyclists and as a fundraiser for the club's other activities. The exact origins of the century ride are unclear, but most agree they were invented in the United States, around the 1890's.
headSection.headingSubText: This was a period when cycling was becoming increasingly popular, and long-distance rides were seen as a test of endurance and fitness. The century ride remains a milestone for many cyclists, symbolizing not just physical endurance but also a love of cycling and a connection to the sport's rich history.

children.value: I remember lying in bed the night before my first 100 km ride, planning the route. Despite having trained consistently for a few months, I wasn’t entirely sure I could complete it, especially in the Carpathians. As a heavier rider, the ascent on the way back worried me a bit. Luckily, once I started the ride, I was so captivated by the beauty of the early morning in the mountains that I completely forgot about it. It was also quite cold outside, and when it's cold, that's all you can really think about.
/cycling/first-100/first-100-route.jpeg
I stayed in HVOYA apart-hotel in Bukovel, plan was to ride from Bukovel west exit -> Bilyn -> Yablunytsia -> Tatariv -> and back to Bukovel but entering from the east.
Some stats from Strava:

value: Distance: 100.01 km
Time total: 4h 30m
Time moving: 3h 42m
Avg speed: 27.0 km/h
Avg HR: 153 bpm
Power: 184 W
Breaks: 1 - hot dog in Yasinia (55km), 2- coffe break in Tatariv (85k)
